bibl.title: Letter from Bert W. Caldwell to Henry Rose Carter, August 5, 1922

div1.p: Caldwell asks Carter to review a report on the yellow fever campaign in Mexico. He discusses the current situation in the field.

div1.head: Letter from Bert W. Caldwell to Henry Rose Carter, August 5, 1922

August 5th, 1922.

Washinton D.C.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I am sending you a copy of my report of
the conduct of the yellow fever campaign in the Second
Yellow Fver Zone during the year 1921-1922. I hope
that you will find time to read it and comment upon it

I have had to take issues with Dr. White
and Connor relative to the time in which intensive
work in my area should be abandoned. I have had to de-
fend my position before the Comision and eveidently w
with success as the entire Mexican membership voted to
continue the work in this area until Dec. 20th and as
long thereafter as conditions made necssary.

My area has been badly infected within
eight months and within five months has reported a
positive case in the area of greatest intensity of in-
fection ten months since. The area seems to be clean
but I don't not believe that it would be wise to aband
-on active work here until this rainy season is over.

Since I completed the report, a positive
case has been reported from Tampico, imported from
Panuco. It rather strengthened my position although
Tampioc-Panuco is in Connor's area not my own. I am
not certain in my own mind that the case was yellow
fever, but as I did not see the case, and as it was
diagnosed by a phsyician, and American who has had
good yellow fever experience, the best that can be said
was that it was suspicious.

I think that we are secure in this area,
but I am not sure. No work is worth doing unless it is
worth doing well. Sufficient time should be given to
demonstrate the effi efficacy of the work ac-
complished.

We will probably give up the active work
in December. The Mexican Government has asked me to
give consideration to the probability of their them
making a proposition to remain with them during the
next year. I am reluctant to do so, and will probably
advise them that I cannot accept. However the work
here may change in such a manner that it will be nec-
cessary for some on to do it, and in that event I will
consider their proposition.

With every good wish, and with my kindest
remembrances to Miss Laura, I remain
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Bert W. Caldwell Calle Constitucion No.13
Vera Cruz Mexico.
